description: From Middle French insecte, from Latin īnsectum (“with a notched or divided body, cut up”), from perfect passive participle of īnsecō (“I cut into, I cut up”), from in- + secō (“I cut”), from the notion that the insect's body is "cut into" three sections (head, thorax, abdomen). Calque of Ancient Greek ἔντομον (éntomon, “insect”), from ἔντομος (éntomos, “cut into pieces”).

entries.meaning: An arthropod (in the Insecta class) characterized by six legs, up to four wings, and a chitinous exoskeleton.
examples: Our shed has several insect infestions, including ants, yellowjackets, and wasps.

entries.meaning: (colloquial) Any small arthropod similar to an insect, including spiders, centipedes, millipedes, etc.
examples: The swamp is swarming with every sort of insect.
The manager’s assistant was the worst sort of insect.
